episodes.title: Missing in Happy Valley (1999)  by Peter Reichelt + Ina Brockmann (Now in 4K)
episodes.description:
25. February 1999 - The ARD - German TV film by TV journalists Peter Reichelt and Ina Brockmann about Scientology's RPF prison camps in USA and Europe:

Missing in the Scientology RPF "Happy Valley"?
The reformatories of the Scientologists
TV - ARD - SWR / NDR / HR / 3 SAT and ORF / 1999 and 2000 - since 2000 various repeats

Stuttgart News
BACKGROUND, 25.02.1999: 
When people disappear in the "Happy Valley" Scientology educates "doubters and failures" behind barbed wire according to its own methods Stuttgart - Scientology maintains penal camps. Until now, there was hardly any information about it. And certainly no pictures. The Mannheim TV journalist Peter Reichelt has succeeded in tracking down reformatories, so-called RPF's (Rehabilitation Project Forces) of the Scientology group.
By our reporter ANTON NOTZ 
Two hours by car from Los Angeles, in a desert-like landscape, lies "Happy Valley." David Miscavage, the head of Scientology, has built an empire nearby that is as luxurious as it is mysterious. In "Happy Valley," however, things are different than in Club Med. Around 100 people from the elite Sea-Org unit have to do their penance here. "The people are real prisoners. They are absolutely not there voluntarily," says Gerry Armstrong, ex-coordinator of the Scientology secret service OSA, who says he spent two and a half years in penal camps. 
Jesse Prince, formerly the second man in the Scientology leadership behind Miscavage, tells Reichelt on camera what goes on behind barbed wire and video-monitored walls. The camp internees have to work day and night like slaves. Prince also speaks from his own experience. He went through Happy Valley for disobeying orders. "It was absolutely horrible. I slept in a chicken coop on the floor, rattlesnakes and scorpions all around me." Hard labor, forced hypnosis, brainwashing - according to dropouts, these are the methods Scientology uses to bring "doubters and failures" back in line. Not all, but those who are significant for the organization because they know too much or are an important cog in the world-spanning money machine. 
How one has to rehabilitate oneself in a penal camp in Copenhagen is described by a once high-ranking Scientologist thus: No newspaper, no radio, talking to no one, eating everyone else's garbage, always working. Everyone is watching everyone else. With "knowledge reports" one blackens the others. The Californian penal camp inside Miscavage's golden cage has another special feature, which Peter Reichelt discovered during a flight over the area: the "track. Jesse Prince explains: Here, some "deadbeats" run around a pole for twelve hours in order to become decent Scientologists again. 
Prince has freed himself from the clutches of the cult group. After numerous death threats, he lives separately from his family to protect them. Peter Reichelt and his colleague Ina Brockmann, who were forcibly detained by Scientology members on the open street during filming, have meanwhile completed a film that will be broadcast today at 10:45 p.m. on Südwest 3. 
Still living in the "Happy Valley" is 51-year-old Wiebke Hansen, in Hamburg for ten years one of the most successful Scientology managers worldwide. In 1995, she disappeared without a trace, but her brother Jochen Körner is now back in contact with her. He was recently able to visit her for a day in Hollywood. Wiebke Hansen produces advertising films for Scientology. In the evening, she returned to "Happy Valley" more or less voluntarily. "Re-education camps, we've had all that before," says Jochen Körner, perplexed. 

Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung
by Michael Hanfeld
25.02.99 
Hubbard's Camp
Scientology up close: "Missing in Happy Valley?" 
Wibke H. was high up. She steered the fortunes of her company throughout Germany. In the first years of her work, she was able to report constantly increasing sales to the headquarters in the United States. Her precipitous fall came when new disciples increasingly failed to materialize. This earned her a trip to "Happy Valley," where she is probably still today, and where, according to the research of Peter Reichelt and Ina Brockmann, it can hardly be very pleasant. For "Happy Valley," according to the findings and the statements of the two television journalists, is a re-education camp where disgraced members of the Scientology organization are kept like slaves and subjected to nasty ordeals. 
A former security chief of the organization, for example, reports on camera how the head of the Scientology security police "SeaOrg," David Miscavige, gets rid of disagreeable employees. 
The authors let the brother of the disappeared Wibke H., with regard to the methods of Scientology described by them, formulate the conclusion: "We've been through this before."

episodes.title: Mark Bunker Says Goodbye in his Last Council Meeting
episodes.description: I had the chance to chair the last council meeting of my term, since the mayor was under the weather.  Knowing it might be the last meeting, I wanted to show my appreciation for the people I work with and the opportunity to serve Clearwater for four years.  I'm proud of what we accomplished and sad that projects I cared about like bringing safety to the people living on Drew Street will be killed. I also regret that the people of Clearwater chose to enact run-offs.  It ensures independent candidates and minorities will find it nearly impossible to ever get elected, crushed by the overwhelming financial power of the establishment.

episodes.title: Why didn’t you have those Scientology Thieves charged?

I wanted to explain why I didn’t think it was necessary to charge the two Scientologists who stole my signs. The financial cost of the yard signs is minor, and they are writing a check to reimburse the campaign, but the cost of eyeballs not seeing my signs leading up to election day is the real harm. Hopefully, getting the story out that Scientologists were so frightened of me winning that they stole the yard signs will make up for some of that damage.

When such divorces happen, a parent can be declared SP by Scientology (Suppressive Person) and no Scientologist is allowed to speak with that individual.  This practice of Disconnection can have a devastating impact on families.

A Scientology audio tape is played into the record.

When such divorces happen, a parent can be declared an SP by Scientology (Suppressive Person) and no Scientologist is then allowed to speak with that individual.  This practice of Disconnection can have a devastating impact on families.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Can Dianetics Cure Arthritis?
episodes.description:
While Tory Christman was still in Scientology, she made the claim that her mother's arthritis was cured with Dianetics.  She and her then husband, Harold Bezazian, were upset and convinced that I would twist their words when I posted the video to the internet.

Scientology is barred by Government law from making any claim of medical cures.  They are federally mandated to post signs in all their buildings and print disclaimers in every publication to that effect.  Yet, anecdotely, this is exactly the type of "win" that is passed on every day by Scientology.

XENU TV
Producer: Mark Bunker

episodes.title: Scientology: Picket at a Celebrity Center Event
episodes.description:
Back in 1999, I videotaped a picket held at Scientology's Celebrity Center in Los Angeles.  Scientologist Harold Bezazian interacts with critics including Garry Scarff.  

Since this picket, Harold has divorced his wife, Tory Christman, after she decided to leave Scientology.  

I like Harold and I always have but now he has written a smear letter against Tory which Scientology has posted on the web.  We believe it was written at Scientology's request because Tory has been interviewed on TV and in print exposing Scientology's fraud and abuse.

XENU TV
Producer: Mark Bunker

After he gave a speech in which he mentioned Scientology, a Scientologist came up to Randi and urged him to try auditing.  I then asked Randi about meeting Scientology's founder, L. Ron Hubbard.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Paulette Cooper
episodes.description:
Paulette Cooper wrote the first critical book about Scientology.  They lashed back with multiple covert operations against her, including setting her up with a roommate who reported on her every move.

www.paulettecooper.com

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Jack Airy on WISE
episodes.description: Jack Airy talks about how he was strong-armed for money as an early user of L. Ron Hubbard's business technology.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Gerry Armstrong on L. Ron Hubbard
episodes.description: Gerry Armstrong was a devoted Sea Org member who was assigned to assist an author hired by Scientology to write a biography of the group's leader, L. Ron Hubbard.  Armstrong uncovered documents about Hubbard's life that showed he had lied about many aspects of his personal history.

episodes.title: Scientology: First Picket from the LMT
episodes.description:
Filmed in January of 2000 -- A few days after the Lisa McPherson Trust opened its doors in Clearwater, Florida (right next to Scientology's dirty tricks division, the Office of Special Affairs) Bob Minton led a small group in a protest of Scientology's abuses.  Then head of OSA, Mike Rinder, attempted to have us arrested.

NOTE: The LMT closed it's doors in late 2001.  The phone number memtioned in the video no longer goes to the LMT.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: The Introspection Rundown
episodes.description: Maureen Bolstad talks about her experiences after suffering a psychotic break in Scientology.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Gary Morehead on Forced Abortions
episodes.description: Gary Morehead ran security at the Int base, Scientology's desert compound near Hemet, California.  Female staffers who became pregnant were coerced into getting abortions so as not to slow down their productivity.  Gary explains how he was involved in the process.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: L. Ron Hubbard's Great-Grandson
episodes.description: Jamie DeWolf talks about the impact Scientology has had on his family.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report:  Lori Hodgson on Disconnection
episodes.description: Scientology's policy of Disconnection breaks up families.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Karen de la Carriere
episodes.description: Karen de la Carriere explains how permission had to be sought to have a child in the Sea Org...even for those in the highest positions in the group.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Jeff Hawkins on the Wog World
episodes.description: Jeff Hawkins talks about Scientology's view of the outside world and how they create an "us vs. them" mentality.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Karen de la Carriere
episodes.description: Karen was married to Heber Jentzsch, then the president of the Church of Scientology, when she was sent off for a six month stint in the Rehabilitation Project Force.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: L. Ron Hubbard and the Evil Psychs
episodes.description: Psychiatrist Dr. Stephen Wiseman believes Hubbard's attacks on "psychs" began because Hubbard looked at himself as a scientist and felt his contributions were diminished by having to turn his "modern science of mental heath" into a religion to avoid trouble with the law.  This was followed closely by the introduction of the first low-cost, effective pill to fight depression (Miltown) which started to dwarf Scientology in the public's eye.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Attorney Denis deVlaming
episodes.description: Clearwater attorney Denis deVlaming talks about how Scientology tried to hire him to sue Mayor Gabe Cazares after the group sneaked into town under a phony name.  Denis would go on to defend critics of Scientology including Bob Minton, Jesse Prince and Mark Bunker.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Christie Collbran on Disconnection
episodes.description: Christie Collbran explains how Scientology's Office of Special Affairs got between her and her parents, severing their relationship.

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Michael Fairman Scientology Ad

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Larry Brennan on Scientology's Religious Cloaking

episodes.title: Knowledge Report: Patty Pieniadz on Knowledge Reports
episodes.description: Scientologists are expected to write reports on others in the group who might not be towing the line.  Former Scientologist Patty Pieniadz talks about how this extends to your closest friends and family members.

The St. Pete Times has just run a story about the $450,000 fine Clearwater has levied against Scientology for not completing construction in a timely manner.

episodes.title: Cults: Robert Lifton Speaks at Conference
episodes.description:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Lifton

Robert Jay Lifton (born May 16, 1926) is an American psychiatrist and author, chiefly known for his studies of the psychological causes and effects of war and political violence and for his theory of thought reform. He was an early proponent of the techniques of psychohistory.

In 2006, Lifton appeared in a documentary on cults on the History Channel: "Decoding the Past", along with fellow psychiatrist Peter A. Olsson

episodes.title: Cults: Dr. Margaret Singer Speaks at Conference
episodes.description:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Singer

Dr. Margaret Thaler Singer, (1921--2003) was a clinical psychologist and Professor Emeritus of the Department of Psychology at the University of California, Berkeley, U.S.

Singer's main areas of research included schizophrenia, family therapy, brainwashing and coercive persuasion. Singer performed research at the University of Colorado's School of Medicine, Walter Reed Army Medical Center Institute of Research, the National Institute of Mental Health, the United States Air Force and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She received many awards for her work, including the Leo J. Ryan Memorial Award, the Research Scientist Award from the National Institute of Mental Health, and both the Hofheimer Prize and the Stanley R. Dean Award from the American College of Psychiatrists.

In the 1960s she began to study the nature of cults and mind control and served on the board of the American Family Foundation. She is the author of the book Cults in Our Midst. She gave expert testimony in several cult-related trials, including the 1976 trial of Patty Hearst, who had previously been kidnapped by the Symbionese Liberation Army, and the 1977 hearing for five members of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church.

In 1987, as head of the APA taskforce on Deceptive and Indirect Techniques of Persuasion and Control for the American Psychological Association, Singer oversaw the production of a report that was later rejected by the APA's Board of Social and Ethical Responsibility for Psychology. Thereafter, Singer's expert testimony in four subsequent cases was not accepted. In 1992 she sued the APA for "defamation, frauds, aiding and abetting and conspiracy", but in 1994 she lost.

Articles in The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times reported complaints by Singer and her family that she had been enduring harassment and death threats due to her "battles" with the cults.

In 2000, Scientology used Nigerian soccer star John Fashanu as the front man for a vicious attack on Bob Minton. They compiled a bogus report claiming that Bob had stolen billions of dollars from Nigeria. Scientology then fed that report to the media to try to get him jailed.

Nine years later, Fashanu has come clean on the report being a sham but it appears he has not yet disclosed Scientology's involvement.

episodes.title: American Psychiatric Association Calls Scientology/CCHR a Hate Group
episodes.description:
Original Text:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- Physicians gathering for the American Psychiatric Association annual meeting here were greeted with a noisy street protest by the Citizens Commission on Human Rights (CCHR), an offshoot of the Church of Scientology. 

From its earliest days in the 1950s, Scientologists have waged a campaign accusing the psychiatric profession of a range of abuses. Now conducted under the CCHR's banner, the campaign currently portrays psychiatry as an "industry of death." 


Demonstrations like the one at this year's meeting have become a fixture at the annual gatherings. 


In this exclusive MedPage Today video report, APA President Nada Stotland, M.D., explains what it's like for a medical society that has, as she put it, its own dedicated hate group -- the impact on practicing psychiatrists, and how the group has responded.

episodes.title: Scientology: Jeff Stone's Changing Story
episodes.description:
PirateofAnonymous has put together this look at how Supervisor Jeff Stone has railroaded an ordinance into place in Riverside County, California  to try to stop protests at Scientology's desert compound near Hemet.  

Called "Gold," this sprawling compound is where Scientology leader David Miscavige lives and rules over the organization.  The gates are constantly guarded, the iron fence covered with spikes and barbed wire to keep members of the Sea Org (Scientology's elite paramilitary unit) from leaving.

Sea Org members sign a billion-year service contract, pledging to return lifetime after lifetime to work for Scientology to help "clear the planet," which means to convert everyone to Scientology.  Some 2% of the population Hubbard described as Suppressive Persons.  SP's should be eliminated "quietly and without sorrow," he wrote.

Sea Org and staff members work about 90 hours a week and get about $50 a week in pay.  They receive one day off every other week unless Scientology feels they are "downstat" (not producing as much as they did the week before)  in which case they lose that privilege.

They are not allowed to come and go as they please, their mail is read and their phone calls are monitored.  They are often cutoff from family members by Scientology's practice of Disconnection.   If a friend or family raises doubts about Scientology, they are told to handle the "Potential Trouble Source."  If the member can not shut-up the person complaining, they are forced to write a Disconnection letter, telling them they will never speak to that person again.  This policy tears many families apart and has even done so to the Miscavige family.

At one point in the 90's, the care of babies was causing too many problems for management and slowing work down so a policy of forced abortions was instituted.  If a Sea Org member got pregnant, they were forced to abort the child or get expelled from their post, thus potentially "losing their eternity."

If someone angers management for any reason, they can be put on the Rehabilitation Project Force.  The RFP is a grueling regimen of hard labor, intensive studying of the tech to correct their thinking and isolation form the rest of the members. Those on the RPF are not permitted to speak to anyone unless spoken to.  They are cut off from husbands or wives for months or even years at a time, until management feels they have groveled enough to return to the group.  They have been forced to run around a pole for eight hours a day in the grueling heat as punishment for an offense, and are fed rice and beans.

It is not possible to just up and leave the Sea Org.  You are expected to "route out" which can take up to six months or paperwork, confessions and auditing during which time they try to convince you to stay.  Should you flee without permission, they have been known to track people down and drag them back.

Whether "blowing" (the process of fleeing) or routing out, a staff or Sea Org member will be hit with a "Freeloader Bill" in the tens of thousands of dollars for all the courses they received in exchange for the slave labor the member has performed.  Usually frightened by the consequences, the ex-member will generally be unaware that this bill is unenforceable in court.  

Members are trained never to go to outside authorities for help.  Any grievance is to be taken to Scientology's internal justice system, so Scientologists are wary of contacting the authorities with their complaints.  Even if they wanted to, they would not be able to make a complaint without Scientology hearing or reading about it as it happens.

These abuses and more are happening in Supervisor Jeff Stone's jurisdiction, under his watch.  But Stone does nothing to stop them.  Instead he accepts campaign contributions from Scientology's leader and jumps to propose a new law to stop the public from speaking out about these abuses.

For this reason, Stone is complicit in the abuse of Scientology's rank and file members.  He should be ashamed of his actions.

http://xenutv.wordpress.com/about-bob-minton-and-the-lmt/

2/12/99 - Although Scientology tried hard to dissuade CULTinfo from allowing Bob to speak, they were not successful. Bob Minton gave an address on the first evening of the conference which was very warmly received.

episodes.title: Scientology: Dr. Norbert Blum Receives 2001 Award
episodes.description: 6/9/01 - Dr. Blum accepts the 2001 Leipzig Human Rights Award.

episodes.title: A Childhood in Scientology
episodes.description: I interview Tanja Neujahr who grew up in Scientology, entered the Cadet, the Sea Org and left the group, only to lose her father who stayed behind.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Disconnection
episodes.description: I interview a woman in Leipzig, Germany who lost a boyfriend to Scientology's policy of disconnection.

episodes.title: Scientology: Jason Beghe Interview
episodes.description: Actor Jason Beghe speaks about his years in Scientology and why he left the group.

episodes.title: Wise Beard Man Returns to YouTube
episodes.description:
HIGH DEF COMING SOON TO VIMEO.

5/2/08 - My channels have been returned to me and our long, national nightmare is over.  Thanks to everyone who contacted YouTube, Viacom and Stephen Colbert on my behalf!  Especially Victoire Flamel and the The Masked Analyst

episodes.title: Scientology:  Tory and Barb at Humanist Society - 1/5
episodes.description: 2/20/05 - Tory Christman and Barbara Graham discuss Scientology at a Humanist Society Meeting in San Diego.  Also attending are several Scientologists who join in on the conversation, including Louis Gonzales and a woman named Wendy who tells many bald-faced lies.

episodes.title: Scientology's Abuse of the Legal System
episodes.description: 3/95 - Former Scientologist Stacy Brooks talks about Hubbard's use of the legal system to destroy critics of the group.  Hubbard wrote that the courts should be used to "ruin them utterly."

episodes.title: Scientology: Can We Ever Be Friends?
episodes.description: 5/6/94 - Former Scientologist Paul Grosswald testifies in a court case on behalf of Tom Padgett who left Scientology while his wife and children stayed in the group. A Scientology audio tape is played into the record. It was made to explain to non-Scientologist parents why they should not be concerned that their child has joined Scientology. It just screams, "CULT!!!!!'

episodes.title: Scientology: Clearwater City Meeting - Redevelopment
episodes.description: 7/20/00 - Bob Minton speaks about the reform of Scientology.  We see Scientology's PR man, Al Buttnor, assemble a response from several Scientologists.

episodes.title: Scientology: Clearwater City Meeting - The LMT Opens
episodes.description: 1/20/00 - Bob Minton speaks at the City Clearwater Commission about the trouble hye had obtaining a building for the LMT in Clearwater.  We also celebrate the former Mayor's 80th birthday.

episodes.title: Scientology: Clearwater City Meeting - LMT Members
episodes.description: 2/3/00 - Stacy Brooks, Jesse Prince and Bob Minton from the Lisa McPherson Trust speak.  Stacy talks about the Clearwater police working for Scientology.  Jesse asks for cooperation with the LMT and Bob talks about Scientology's influence with the city manager.

episodes.title: Scientology: Clearwater City Meeting - Scientology Influence
episodes.description: 3/16/00 - Bob Minton talks about the meeting he had with City Manager Mike Roberto who had cozied up to Scientology and threatened to shut the LMT down for "stirring up trouble."

episodes.title: Scientology:  The Shrinking World of L. Ron Hubbard
episodes.description: 1967 - Important documentary about the founder of Scientology.  A rarecase where Hubbard was interviewed by an outside news crew.

episodes.title: Scientology:   Attorney Graham Berry
episodes.description:
Article: http://tinyurl.com/6yveew 

Graham Berry has been involved in several suits against Scientology. They they set out to "ruin him utterly" per Hubbard's orders.  In this case, a man who was paid by Scientology to smear Graham in court, changed sides and admitted what he had been paid to do by Scientology.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Tory Speaks in Los Angeles - Part 5
episodes.description: 3/7/05 - Tory Christman was in Scientology for 30 years.  This was the first speech she gave about her experiences in front of a large, receptive crowd.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Clearwater City Meeting - Abuses
episodes.description: Jeff Jacobsen responds to an article in the St. Petersburg Times in which it was stated that Clearwater Police Chief Sid Klein thought it was time to remove the police from their off duty Scientology assignments.  I present the city with copies of interviews about Scientology abuse which can be viewed online at www.xenutv.com.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Clearwater City Meeting - Statue for Gabe
episodes.description: I speak before the Clearwater Mayor and City Commission and inform them of the latest unethical activities of Scientology.  I suggest they erect a stature to the former mayor of the city who fought Scientology aggressively, Gabe Cazares.  Scientologist Loren Westenberger responds.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Clearwater City Meeting - School Award
episodes.description: I speak before the Mayor and City Commission to tell them how they were used by Scientology.

episodes.title: Scientology:   A Tour of Clearwater
episodes.description: Retired Police Lt. Ray Emmons gives us a tour of Scientology's properties in Clearwater, Florida.

episodes.title: Scientology:   Picket on Hollywood Blvd.
episodes.description:
Tory Christman, Jeff Jacobsen, Feisty and others picketed Scientology in Los Angeles. This picket was used to draw attention to Sheriff Lee Baca's support of the Scientology front group Narconon.

They started in front of Baca's offices but by the time I caught up with them they had moved on to the L. Ron Hubbard Life Exhibition on Hollywood Blvd.

episodes.title: Scientology:   Chariots of Fraud
episodes.description: When Scientology sponsored a "Say No to Drugs" race, we attended to inform the runners that Scientology is specifically opposed to psychotropic drugs, not just street drugs.

episodes.title: Scientology: Bumpgate
episodes.description: While videotaping a picket, I bumped into a Scientology security guard by mistake.  He called the police to charge me with assault.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Andreas in Hollywood - Part 1
episodes.description:
Andreas's site: http://www.xenu.net
Scientology smear site: http://www.religiousfreedomwatch.org

Andreas Heldal-Lund, the webmaster of the most important site critical of Scientology came to L.A. to visit from his home country of Norway.  When Andreas joined a picket, he was greeted by a Scientologist with a camera who wanted to interview him.  I taped virtually the entire encounter.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Andreas in Hollywood - Part 2
episodes.description: Andreas Heldal-Lund, the webmaster of the most important site critical of Scientology (www.xenu.net) came to L.A. to visit from his home country of Norway.  When Andreas joined a picket, he was greeted by a Scientologist with a camera who wanted to interview him.  I taped virtually the entire encounter.

episodes.title: Scientology:  The Revenge Picket
episodes.description: One day after I videotaped a picket of Scientology, my neighborhood was covered with leaflets smearing me.  Shortly after, two Scientologists showed up at my home to picket me.

episodes.title: Scientology:  TR demo
episodes.description: This is a demonstration of the basic drills done by Scientologists when joining the group.  It shows how Scientologists are trained to command people and be commanded themselves.  It gives an idea how the indoctrination process begins.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Day 2 of the Fourth Of July Event
episodes.description:
Watch the exciting conclusion at Vimeo:  https://vimeo.com/27952325

7/3/99 - I return to L. Ron Hubbard Way and am again thwarted in my attempt to walk down the public street.

episodes.title: Scientology:  L. Ron Hubbard's Great-Grandson
episodes.description: Jamie Kennedy, the great-grandson of the founder of Scientology, speaks out against the organization on the Bubba the Love Sponge radio show.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Day 1 of the Fourth Of July Event
episodes.description: 7/2/99 - I attempt to shoot a little video of a Scientology event and am surrounded by three Scientologists who try to intimidate me with a Scientology technique called "bullbaiting."

episodes.title: Scientology and the Clearwater Police
episodes.description: A documentary from 2000 when the Clearwater Police were working their off duty hours for Scientology.  I was working with a group opposed to Scientology.  This video exposed what I believed to be a bias against us.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Tory and Bob Minton in a Food Fight
episodes.description: Tory Christman was in Scientology for 30 years.  Bob Minton helped ehr when she left the group.  While visiting Bob's home in New Hampshire, Tory initiated a fiood fight.

episodes.title: Scientology:  Tory Christman Music Video
episodes.description: Tory was in Scientology for 30 years before she left the group in 2000.  This video salute was edited together for Tory's birthday.
